items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.81mAOD at 06:45 on 24/08/24 and 4.70mAOD at 18:45 on 24/08/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 19 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 20:00 on 24/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood Alert remains in force due to strong winds, surge, and high spring tides on the coast from today, Saturday 24/08/2024 and over the coming days. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads in the Spurn Road, Southfield Farm and Kilnsea Caravan park areas. Flooding of coastal roads and footpaths along coast frontages is likely. Flooding is possible between 8.15am and 11am today, Saturday 24/08/2024 and again between 9.30am and 12.30pm tomorrow, Sunday 25/08/2024. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We are closely monitoring the situation. Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9.00pm on Saturday 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Saturday's early morning tide at 03:00 on 24/08/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with light Southerly Force 2 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 6.08 metres Chart Datum (3.03 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields, including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:45 on 24/08/2024 is forecast to be the same height (3.03 mAOD). Similar minor flood impacts are predicted again at each high tideâ€š but should reduce from Sunday (25/08/2024). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Take care if visiting Climping beach. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 24/08/2024.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 15:30 and 17:30, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46mAODN at 16:30, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.32m above tide tables, wind Force 3, in a south westerly direction. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 18:00 today, Saturday 24 August.

items.description: Tyne estuary

floodArea.county: Gateshead, Newcastle upon Tyne, North Tyneside, South Tyneside

items.message:
High tides are expected due to a combination of high spring tides and a storm surge following Storm Lilian. Strong winds may cause large waves within the estuary tomorrow morning, 23/08/2024. Tides will be at their highest between 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 with wave overtopping possible during these times. The area most likely to be affected is Newcastle Quayside.
 
This alert is in force for the this evenings high tide, Thursday (22/08/2024) Friday mornings tide (23/08/2024), and Saturday mornings tide (24/08/24). 
High tides are anticipated between 17:30 and 19:30, 22/08/2024, 05:15 and 07:15, 23/08/2024 and 06:00 and 08:00 24/08/2024. The flood risk impacts will be highest on the Friday morning tide, 23/08/2024. Please remain vigilant for any potential flood warnings around Newcastle Quayside.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please stay away from riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads as high water levels, large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 14:45 and 16:45, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.81mAODN at 15:45, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.15m above tide tables, wind Force 2, in a northerly direction. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 18:00 today, Saturday 24 August.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 14:45 and 16:45, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51mAODN at 15:45, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind Force 2, in a northerly direction. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 18:00 today, Saturday 24 August.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 14:45 and 16:45, Saturday 24 August. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51mAODN at 15:45, Saturday 24 August, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind Force 2, in a northerly direction. items.description: Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River and lake levels in the area will remain high due to recent rainfall.  We are expecting a drier day today with occasional showers,  meaning levels will fall throughout today 24/08/2024.  We are expecting further rain Sunday 25/8/24 which will keep levels higher than normal but we are not expecting this to cause any increase to current levels. 

Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/08/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are expecting further rain Sunday 25/8/24 which will keep levels higher than normal but we are not expecting this to cause any increase to current levels.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water. items.description: West Dorset Rivers and Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message: River levels have risen at the Bridport Gundry river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Consequently there may be flooding of low lying areas. We expect flooding to potentially affect the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride. River levels can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 4:00 PM on 25/08/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cole, Dorcan Brook and South Marston Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Cole as a result of localised thunderstorms. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible on 24/08/2024 in the morning. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to rise until the afternoon on24/08/2024. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow afternoon, 24/08/2024, or as the situation changes.
